senses.sense_definition: Any state of complete disorder and confusion.

examples.text: The sudden cancellation of the trains caused <w>chaos</w> for commuters.
After the earthquake, the city descended into <w>chaos</w>.

senses.sense_definition: A behavior of complex systems in physics and mathematics where small changes in initial conditions result in large, unpredictable differences later.

examples.text: Meteorologists study <w>chaos</w> to understand why weather is so hard to predict.
The concept of <w>chaos</w> theory explains how a butterfly flapping its wings might cause a storm.

senses.sense_definition: The formless and disordered state of matter that existed before the creation of the universe in classical accounts of cosmogony.

examples.text: Ancient myths often describe the world emerging from primordial <w>chaos</w>.
The creator brought structure to the formless <w>chaos</w>.

senses.sense_definition: In Greek mythology, the first primordial deity or the void state preceding the creation of the universe.

examples.text: According to Hesiod, <w>Chaos</w> existed before all other gods.
From <w>Chaos</w> came Erebus and dark Night.

senses.sense_definition: A trans-Neptunian object orbiting in the Kuiper belt.

examples.text: Astronomers have identified <w>Chaos</w> as a cubewano in the outer solar system.
The orbit of <w>Chaos</w> lies far beyond that of Neptune.
